item.title: A start to C++
item.dc:creator: @super_OLDACCOUNT super_OLDACCOUNT
item.description:
@super_OLDACCOUNT wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:13, topic:170635”][quote author=super_ link=topic=230595.msg2061355#msg2061355 date=1203324402]
wait, i thought this was c++, ya no, where it’s discouraged to use preprocessor constants.it’s also discouraged to ‘use’ an entire namespace when there is only a practical amount of members your accessing from it.
[/quote]

Oh c’mon, the guy just started, you could ease up on the attitude.

Also, the use of “using” is purely a personal thing, I know people that never use it, and people that will use it to extremes. Personally, in your own code, I’d say go ahead and “use” as much as you want, it’s only when writing reusable code that will actually be reused (a library) that it’s really an issue worth bitching about.

EDIT: Also, I’m really confused as to why you converted a C++ string to a char array, then to an int, then back to a C++ string, for no real reason.[/quote]
back to a c++ string? i think not. and the to-char-array is because atoi() in cstdlib takes a char * as it’s argument, not a std::string object. i see i could’ve also used stringstream as he did, but see i am tired.

Read full topic

item.title: A start to C++
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

super_:

wait, i thought this was c++, ya no, where it’s discouraged to use preprocessor constants.it’s also discouraged to ‘use’ an entire namespace when there is only a practical amount of members your accessing from it.

Oh c’mon, the guy just started, you could ease up on the attitude.

Also, the use of “using” is purely a personal thing, I know people that never use it, and people that will use it to extremes. Personally, in your own code, I’d say go ahead and “use” as much as you want, it’s only when writing reusable code that will actually be reused (a library) that it’s really an issue worth bitching about.

EDIT: Also, I’m really confused as to why you converted a C++ string to a char array, then to an int, then back to a C++ string, for no real reason.

Read full topic

item.title: A start to C++
item.dc:creator: @super_OLDACCOUNT super_OLDACCOUNT
item.description:
@super_OLDACCOUNT wrote:

its called atoi(). way to create useless objects.
wait, i thought this was c++, ya no, where it’s discouraged to use preprocessor constants.
it’s also discouraged to ‘use’ an entire namespace when there is only a practical amount of members your accessing from it.

[code]#include
#include

using std::string;
using std::cout;
using std::cin;
using std::endl;

const float CM = 2.54;

int main() {
string tmp;
int inches = 0;
cout << "Enter the number of inches: ";
getline(cin, tmp);
inches = atoi(tmp.c_str());
cout << inches << " inches is " << inches * CM << endl;
return (0);
}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: A start to C++
item.dc:creator: @spankjava spank
item.description:
@spankjava wrote:

Thanks this is a small game i just finished just noticed your post and ill take them in cosideration

[code=cpp]#include
using namespace std;

int main()
{
int wins = 0;
int num = 0;
int guess = 0;
loop:
srand(time(NULL));

num = 1 + rand() % (6 - 1 + 1);
cout <<"\nPlays: ";
cout << wins << "\n";
cout <<"Guess the number come on give it ago\n";
cin >> guess;
        cout << "The number was " << num << "\n";
if (guess == num)
{

cout << “you WIN \n”;
wins++;
goto loop;}
else
cout << " you LOSE \n";
goto loop;
}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: A start to C++
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

just a couple things…

istream’s extraction operator supports ints, so you can simplify your code to:

cin >> Amount;

removing the need for the stringstream object… also, you shouldn’t use system(“pause”); as it is terribly inefficient (it creates two programs in order to pause yours)… so instead use

cin.ignore(10, ‘\n’); // i personally use this to extract any new lines still in the stream that might make it skip cin.get()
cin.get(); // waits for the user to press enter

also, instead of using the whole std namespace, you can specify certain objects to use so you’re not needlessly including things you won’t use… for example:

using std::cout;
using std::cin;
using std::endl;

that way if you use a variable whose name is already defined in the std namespace (for example “var1”) the compiler won’t automatically assume you want to use std’s var1 (because you specifically only included cout, cin, and endl) and will use your var1

Read full topic

item.title: A start to C++
item.dc:creator: @spankjava spank
item.description:
@spankjava wrote:

Well About 2 hours ago i started reading up on C++ and i put decided to make a small programm that benifited me so i made a small program that converts inches into centimeters.

[code=cpp]
#include
#include
#include
using namespace std;

#define CM 2.54

int main ()
{
string inches;
int Amount =0;
cout << “Enter The Number Of Inches “;
getline (cin, inches);
stringstream(inches) >> Amount;
cout << Amount << " Inchs Is " << Amount*CM;
cout <<” Cm’s”;
cout <<"\n";
system(“pause”);
return 0;
}[/code]

Read full topic
